metadata.title: Synthesis of Co-N-C grafted on well-dispersed MnO<ce:inf loc=post>x</ce:inf>-CeO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> hollow mesoporous sphere with efficient catalytic performance

Research Paper Synthesis of Co-N-C grafted on well-dispersed MnOx-CeO2 hollow mesoporous sphere with efficient catalytic performance Xiu Lin a Sufang Zhao a Lingling Fu a Yongming Luo b Runliang Zhu c ⁎ Zhigang Liu a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Chemo/Biosensing and Chemometrics, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, Hunan, China State Key Laboratory of Chemo/Biosensing and Chemometrics School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hunan University Changsha Hunan 410082 China b Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650500, Yunan, China Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming Yunan 650500 China c Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Mineral Physics and Material Research & Development, Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou 510640, Guangdong, China Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Mineral Physics and Material Research & Development Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Guangzhou Guangdong 510640 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Metal oxide hollow sphere have emerged as a kind of promising nanostructured materials for catalysis, energy conversion, and storage capacity. Herein, a “silica-protective-layer-assisted” approach is adopted to synthesize Co-N-C supported MnOx-CeO2 hollow mesoporous spheres, which can effectively suppress the sintering of metal oxide. The metal oxide hollow mesoporous spheres are prepared through silica template, MnOx-CeO2 shell, cobalt porphyrin precursor, and silica protective layer via a layer-by-layer strategy. The Co-N-C/MnOx-CeO2 catalysts show a remarkable catalytic performance for the oxidation of ethylbenzene (ethylbenzene conversion to 44.5%). Moreover, the catalysts have well-defined morphology, homogeneously dispersed, high specific surface area and porous structure. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to the hollow hierarchically mesoporous structure and the synergistic effect between oxygen vacancy and Co-Nx active sites derived from the pyrolysis of cobalt-N4 macrocycles of cobalt porphyrin. Keywords Co-N-C MnOx-CeO2 Ethylbenzene oxidation Hollow mesoporous structure Synergistic effect Introduction Over the past decades, nanostructured materials with controlled size and morphology have been prepared and widely involved in many fields because of their unique structure features [1–3]. It is well-known that porosity and specific surface area play important factors in affecting the performance of materials [3]. Thus, hollow mesoporous spheres have attracted tremendous attention due to their high porosity, low density and high specific surface area [4,5] , and are broadly applied into drug delivery, supercapacitors, energy storage and conversion, catalytic applications and so on [6–9]. In recent years, metal oxide hollow mesoporous sphere has attracted more and more researchers interests because of their wide applications including separations, delivery and release of drugs, as well as heterogeneous and electrochemical catalysis and so on [10–12]. For example, Lou et al. have reported that metal oxide hollow materials are superior electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries because metal oxide hollow structure endows the superior rate capability, high specific capacity and improved cycling performance [12]. Transition metal oxide (TMOs) involving with different metal elements (Fe, Co, Mn, Zn, etc.) have presented extensively application prospects [6,8,12]. Cerium oxide (CeO2) has widely employed as catalysts due to its intrinsic chemical properties such as high oxygen mobility, and high oxygen storage and release capacity [13,14]. Thus, a large number of reports about MOx-CeO2 composites, especially for MnOx-CeO2, have been reported to explore their potential applications including CO oxidation, NO reduction, ammonia oxidation, and other oxidation reactions for hydrocarbons [15–18]. However, it is noteworthy that metal oxide is easily sintered to form composites with irregular morphology during heating, which impede the further improvement of catalytic performance. Therefore, Yin et al. have reported the crystallization of mesoporous hollow TiO2 nanostructure with a high surface area can be controlled via a silica-protected calcination process [19]. And Joo et al. have also utilized silica layer protected method to prepare the Fe-Nx active sites on the carbon nanotube (CNT) [20]. However, the activity of nanoscale metal oxide still needs to be further enhanced even although they have presented well-defined structure. The immobilization of noble metals onto MnOx-CeO2 composites is typically recommended as a successful strategy for the improvement of catalytic activity, such as Ru/MnOx-CeO2, Pt/MnOx-CeO2, Pd/MnOx-CeO2 and Au/MnOx-CeO2 [21–23]. Although these noble metal catalysts have an excellent catalytic performance, the prohibitive cost seriously blocks a wide range of commercial applications. The transition metal (e.g. Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, etc.) coordinated N-doped carbon (Metal-N-C) has been explored in many fields owning to their remarkable catalytic performance and substitutions for noble metal catalysts [24–27]. Metal-N-C is usually prepared via pyrolysis of organic molecular compounds, polymers and nitrogen-containing carbon precursors [27]. Previous reports have shown that Metal-N-C catalysts from metalloporphyrin exhibit excellent catalytic performance in the oxidation of organic compounds and electrochemistry due to the unique skeleton of metal-Nx macrocycles [28,29]. Additionally, the Metal-Nx that can be the active center of Metal-N-C from metalloporphyrins, holding excellent catalytic performance in various applications [29,30]. Thus, it is worth looking forward to the research work that Metal-N-C loads onto MnOx-CeO2 composites. Herein, we combine the MnOx-CeO2 hollow porous shell structure and cobalt nitrogen doped carbon (Co-N-C) to synthesize an excellent catalyst that Co-N-C grafted on MnOx-CeO2 hollow mesoporous sphere (MCHS) via a layer-by-layer strategy. In this process, silica sphere is the sacrificial hard template of MnOx-CeO2 hollow mesoporous shell and cobalt (II) 5-(4-carboxyphenyl)-10,15,20-triphenyl porphyrin-modified (CoTPP) used as the precursor of Co-N-C. The silica coating can effectively mitigate the sintering of hollow meosoporous metal oxide spheres at high temperatures. The catalysts are characterized by techniques such as TEM, HRTEM, BET, Raman, XPS, etc. And the catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts for the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene oxidation has been investigated. Experimental section Materials Ammonium (25%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), ethylene glycol, manganese (II) chloride (MnCl2·4H2O), cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O), thionyl chloride, chloroform (CHCl3), (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), triethylamine, toluene, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), propanoic acid, benzaldehyde, 4-carboxybenzaldehyde, pyrrole, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, K30). All chemicals are used without further purification. Synthesis of MCHS MCHS was synthesized according to a layer-by-layer strategy [31]. 30mL deionized water containing 0.10g SiO2@MnOx-CeO2 particle (see the Supporting information) was mixed with 0.15g PVP at room temperature under magnetic stirring. After being refluxed for 3h at 100°C, the PVP treated sample was collected by centrifugation and re-dispersed in the solution of 60mL ethanol, 12mL deionized water and 5mL ammonium hydroxide, followed by the addition of 40mL ethanol solution containing 0.17mL TEOS. The mixture was kept stirring for another 3h at room temperature. The product was separated, washed with ethanol, and dried in vacuum oven, then heated in N2 atmosphere at 500°C for 1h, denoted as SiO2@MnOx-CeO2@SiO2. The as-prepared product 0.07g sample was dispersed in 30mL deionized water. NaOH solution (2.5M, 1mL) was added magnetic stirring and heated at 50°C for 80min. After separating and washing with 100mL deionized water and 50mL ethanol, the MnOx-CeO2 hollow sphere was obtained and assigned as MCHS. Synthesis of Co-N-C/MCHS Co-N-C/MCHS was synthesized by heating cobalt (II) 5-(4-carboxyphenyl)-10,15,20-triphenyl porphyrin modified with APTES (CoTPP) (see the Supporting information) grafted on SiO2@MnOx-CeO2. The CoTPP and 0.24g SiO2@MnOx-CeO2 were loaded in 60mL toluene under vigorous stirring at 75°C for 24h. The CoTPP coating metal oxide solid sphere (named SiO2@(CoTPP/MnOx-CeO2)) was separated by filtration, washed, dried and then heated in N2 atmosphere at 500°C for 1h and denoted as (SiO2@(Co-N-C/MnOx-CeO2)). The as-obtained product (0.10g) was treated with polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (0.15g) for 3h at 100°C in 30mL deionized water before redispersing in 60mL ethanol with magnetic stirring, followed by sequential addition of 12mL H2O, 5mL ammonium hydroxide solution, and 40mL ethanol solution containing 0.17mL TEOS. The mixture was kept stirring at room temperature for 3h. The product was collected by centrifugation and washed with ethanol, and then heated in N2 at 500°C for 1h to form SiO2@(Co-N-C/MnOx-CeO2)@SiO2. The as-prepared sample was dispersed in 30mL deionized water. NaOH solution (2.5M, 1mL) was added magnetic stirring and heated at 50°C for 80min. After separating and washing with 100mL deionized water and 50mL ethanol, the Co-N-C/metal oxide hollow sphere was obtained and assigned as Co-N-C/MCHS. As a control group, Co-N-C was obtained by pyrolysis of CoTPP in N2 atmosphere at 500°C for 1h. MnOx-CeO2 nanoparticles were synthesized by a coprecipitation process similar to that of SiO2@MnOx-CeO2. And then MnOx-CeO2 nanoparticles, denoted as MCN, are obtained after being heated in N2 atmosphere at 500°C for 1h. Co-N-C/MCN was prepared as a similar synthetic method. Measurement of catalytic performance Typically, 28mg catalysts and 10mL ethylbenzene were transferred into a 50mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and then heated to 140°C and kept for 5h under 0.8MPa O2. The oxidation products were analyzed by gas chromatography Shimadzu GC-2014 equipped with a capillary column (RTX-5, 30m, φ 0.25mm) with internal standard method using bromobenzene and 1,4-dichlorobenzene as references. The reused catalysts were obtained by centrifugation, washing with ethanol and drying at 80°C in air. The catalytic results were the average of three experiments, and the data were in error within 1%. Characterization The textual property of catalysts was measured by nitrogen adsorption/desorption at 77K on NOVA 1000e from Quanta Chrome Instruments. The samples were degassed at 100°C for 6h prior to adsorption experiments. The phase analysis of samples was carried out by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD-6100). The morphology of samples was measured by Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on FEI Quanta 200 and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with an electron microscope operating at an 80kV voltage on JEOL-2100. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) were performed on JEM-2100F. The Raman spectra were recorded with a Renishaw 1000 spectrometer using a 632.8nm He-Ne laser operating at 2mW. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were evaluated on a RBD upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) with Mg Kα radiation (h=1253.6eV) or Al Kα radiation (hν=1486.6eV). Results and discussion The Co-N-C/MCHS hollow sphere is prepared by a facile method employing silica sphere as sacrificial templates. The fabrication process of Co-N-C/MCHS is shown in Scheme 1 . The silica sphere templates used in this study are well-defined with a diameter of ∼90nm (Fig. S1a). In the synthesis process of SiO2@MnOx-CeO2 particles, cerium and manganese species can be homogeneously deposited on the surface of silica sphere through self-assembly in ethylene glycol solution. There are a large number of mesopores distributing on the shell due to CeO2 nanoparticles shell [20]. The MnOx-CeO2 hierarchically porous shells endow Co-N-C/MCHS with well permeability for substrate so as to improve catalytic performance, and the oxygen vacancies of CeO2 are also beneficial to chemical reactions [18]. The silica protective layer covers the surface of CoTPP/metal oxide sphere in order to protect metal nanoparticles from sintering during the calcination. The structure and morphology of catalysts are first investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As shown in Fig. 1 , the MnOx-CeO2 and silica layer with a thickness of 21nm can be easily observed, and the SiO2@MnOx-CeO2@SiO2 sphere with a diameter of about 133nm (Fig. 1a and b). The thickness of MnOx-CeO2 and silica layer decrease obviously (15nm) after heating treatment (Fig. 1c and d), which may be due to the collapse of the pores during the pyrolysis process. The MnOx-CeO2 hollow sphere with a thickness of 18nm is subsequently achieved via a chemical etching process in sodium hydroxide solution (Fig. 1d and f). The above results show that this method is feasible, and provides a good platform for our further work. As shown in Fig. 2 , the TEM images clearly present that SiO2@(Co-N-C/MnOx-CeO2)@SiO2 and Co-N-C/MCHS are homogeneously dispersed and well-defined morphology. The outer surface color of Co-N-C/MCHS is significant dark than that of MCHS (Fig. S1b and c), which is may be due to the carbonization of CoTPP to Co-N-C. Compared with SiO2@MnOx-CeO2@SiO2 (Fig. 1c and d), SiO2@(Co-N-C/MnOx-CeO2)@SiO2 maintains the similar morphology (Fig. 2a and b). The TEM images further show well-defined interior structure of Co-N-C/MCHS with a shell of ∼18nm in thickness (Fig. 2c and d), and hierarchically pore channels can also be observed in Fig. 2e. In addition, it is reported that large hollow cavity (∼100nm) provides a unique microenvironment for the reactions, while porous shell offers diffusion pathways for reactants or products [32]. The lattice spacing are measured to 0.310 and 0.213nm (Fig. 2f), which are consistent with CeO2 and CoO, respectively [33,34]. This result is also proved by the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 3 a). The characteristic diffraction peaks of MCN, Co-N-C/MCN, MCHS, and Co-N-C/MCHS can be assigned to the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 crystals (JCPDS 34-0394), indexing to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), and (400) planes [33]. However, there have no characteristic peaks of cobalt species appearing except the spectra of Co-N-C, revealing that they are likely presenting an amorphous state and a relatively high dispersion [35]. And manganese species are not observed in these samples, it is due to low content and high dispersion of manganese species. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) is applied in order to show an insight into the element distribution of Co-N-C/MCHS. The elemental mappings results prove the existence of cobalt, carbon and nitrogen element, and their high dispersion degree over the three-dimensional MCHS (Fig. 4 ). The physical properties of catalysts are evaluated via nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms. These materials possess a characteristic type IV isotherm with a H2 hysteresis loop which means the existence of mesoporous structure (Fig. 3b). The specific surface areas of MCHS (153m2/g) and Co-N-C/MCHS (128m2/g) calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method are larger than that of MCN and Co-N-C (Table 1 ). And the pore diameter of Co-N-C/MCHS derived from the desorption branch of isotherm calculated using Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) mode present hierarchically mesoporous in 3–15nm of pore distribution (Fig. 3c), evidenced by the TEM image (Fig. 2e). The MnOx-CeO2 shell presents hierarchically mesoporous structure but there is no hierarchically mesoporous structure in MCN (Fig. S3). Co-N-C/MCHS has a lower specific surface area, more narrow average pore size and smaller pore volume in comparison with MCHS, which is attributed to the loading of Co-N-C that occupies pore channels of MCHS. This is the reason why the specific surface area of Co-N-C/MCN is less than that of MCN. The structural characteristics of the catalysts are examined by Raman (Fig. 3d). The band at 456cm−1 is attributed to vibration modes of the Ce-8O unit (triply degenerate F2g mode) of CeO2 [36]. A small red shift is observed in the fluorite F2g band of MCN, MCHS and Co-N-C/MCHS, compared with a pure CeO2 nanoparticles (463cm−1) [37]. This findings are related to the incorporation of a small amount of manganese species to the fluorite lattice and the coexistence of Co-N-C and bimetallic oxides, which is apparently in good agreement with the elemental mappings (Fig. 4). In addition, the band at 631cm−1 is ascribed to oxygen vacancies in the fluorite ceria lattice of the Mn-containing samples, which results from the presence of a small amount of the manganese in the lattice as a consequence of charge compensation [37]. The typical D band at 1329cm−1 is associated with defects of carbon and G band at 1582cm−1 is corresponding to graphitic carbon [38]. The IC of Co-N-C/MCHS (1.01) is lower than that of Co-N-C (1.28), indicating a reduced graphitic crystalline structure compared with Co-N-C, which further demonstrates the successful immobilization of cobalt nitrogen doped materials [39]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is employed to investigate the influence of the chemical state of surface species. There is a comparison of Co 2p spectra between Co-N-C/MCHS and Co-N-C in Fig. 5 a. Apparently, the Co 2p3/2 (780.4eV) peak intensity of Co-N-C/MCHS is lower than that of Co-N-C, which is due to lower cobalt content. The Co 2p3/2 is divided into two peaks that locate at 779.7 and 781.3eV, corresponding to Co3+ and Co2+, respectively [40]. And a weak satellite peak at 785.4eV is observed. These results demonstrate these peaks are attributed to the Co3O4 phase [41]. The Mn 2p spectrum is recorded in Fig. 5b. The curve of Mn 2p clearly manifest two mainly peaks with binding energies of 641.8 and 653.4eV, which is ascribed to the Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 states, respectively. The spin orbit splitting is calculated to 11.6eV (ΔE=Mn 2p1/2-Mn 2p3/2), which is similar with the value of MnO2 (11.7eV) [18]. Furthermore, the Mn 2p3/2 is fitted with Shirley background and 30:70 of Lorentzian:Gaussian model functions. Three peaks with the banding energy value of 640.5, 641.8 and 643.7eV are obtained, suggesting that the co-existence of Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ ions based on standard binding energy and previous reports [17,18]. Meanwhile, the fitted Ce 3d spectra of Co-N-C/MCHS are shown in Fig. 5c, where the Ce 3d levels are comprised of 10 various states. The peaks including u‴, u″, u, v‴, v″ and v are assigned to Ce4+ species while u′ u0, v′ and v0 are attributed to Ce3+ species [23,42]. It is observed that the oxidation state of Ce is predominantly tetravalent, which suggest that manganese ions have no significant effect on the oxidation state of cerium [43,44]. Thus, it also proves the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ species on the surface of the composites. Reddy et al. have reported that the Ce3+ ions could be beneficial for the generation of oxygen vacancy and activation of surface oxygen species, improving the catalytic activity [18]. As in Fig. 5d, a shoulder O 1s peak is observed which is maybe due to the overlapping contributions of various oxygen species. The O 1s profile is deconvoluted into three chemical states of oxygen species, namely lattice oxygen atoms (O2−, 529.4eV), surface adsorbed oxygen (O2−, O2 2−, O−, 531.2eV), and adsorbed molecular water (532.3eV) [44]. The oxygen vacancies can be produced due to the presence of Ce3+ ions that is also favorable to create the surface adsorbed oxygen [18]. According to literatures, the surface adsorbed oxygens from defective sites with an unsaturated structure are of extraordinary significance in the catalytic oxidation procedure [18]. Moreover, the N 1s spectra of Co-N-C/MCHS is shown in Fig. 5e, which reveals three peaks at 398.5, 399.8, and 401.3eV corresponding to pyridinic N and Co-Nx, pyrrolic N and graphitic N, respectively [45,46]. And the various nitrogen types are described in Fig. 5f. The pyridinic N and graphitic N are derived from the pyrrolic nitrogen of cobalt porphyrin via calcination in which pyridinic N is possibly attached to the edges of nitrogen-doped carbon lattice and bonded with cobalt to form Co-Nx, which may play an important role in the catalytic activity [29,47,48]. The content of various elements is shown in Table 1, there is apparently no direct relationship among these data. However, it is worth noting that C is the predominant element in MCHS, the reason is that the carbon element is originated from carbonaceous exterior surface via the calcination of PVP [32]. The ethylbenzene oxidation reaction is used to evaluate the catalytic performance of catalysts, because the process for oxidation of ethylbenzene is of great value in chemical industry [49]. The main products of this reaction are acetophenone (AP), 1-phenyl ethanol (PE), and benzaldehyde (BA), as presented in Table 2 . Co-N-C shows the worst catalytic activity (27.1%). However, Co-N-C/MCHS with the best ethylbenzene conversion (44.5%) is larger than that of MCHS, Co-N-C/MCN, and MCN, suggesting that Co-Nx active sites and hollow structure play an important role in improving catalytic activity. However, the selectivity of Co-N-C/MCHS (66.1%) is slightly lower than that of MCHS and MCN (around 72.5%), but larger than that of Co-N-C (59.5%), demonstrating that the MnOx-CeO2 composites are helpful to improve the selectivity of ethylbenzene oxidation, which may be due to the effect of surfaced absorbed oxygen and oxygen vacancies from CeO2 [44]. Compared with MCN, MCHS exhibits better ethylbenzene conversions than MCN (Table 1), indicating that the hollow hierarchically mesoporous structure facilitate the transfer of substrate molecules and the contact with oxygen [20,32]. Furthermore, the hollow porous sphere can provide more active sites owing to the explosion of the crystal facets, edges, and corners. However, the activity of Co-N-C/MCHS is higher than that of MCHS. It has been reported that the employment of transition metals or organometallic centers is critical for the activation of ethylbenzene [50]. Müllen et al. have reported an excellent catalyst from heating metalloporphyrins with Metal-N as the active species [29]. Additionally, in our previous reported, it has been proved that Co-Nx may be the primary active sites among the cobalt compounds (e.g., CoO, Co2O3, Co3O4 and Co-Nx) after the pyrolysis of cobalt porphyrin [30,34]. Co-N-C/MCN has a higher activity compared with MCN, but less than Co-N-C/MCHS, this further proves the significance of hollow mesoporous structure that can inhibit the aggregation of metal active species and improve their dispersion. This result can be authenticated by Fig. S2 with clearly aggregation for MnOx-CeO2 nanoparticles. And the reusability of the MCHS and Co-N-C/MCHS catalysts are investigated and shown in Fig. 6 . The ethylbenzene conversion over catalyst in six runs has only slightly drop (remains ca. 27.9% for MCHS and 38% for Co-N-C/MCHS), it is due to the inevitable mass loss of catalyst during recovered and reused (Table 1). But Co-N-C/MCHS shows better catalytic selectivity than MCHS in the sixth cyclic reaction. And Co-N-C/MCHS retains nearly intact hollow mesoporous structure even after recycling six times (Figs. S4 and S5), despite the specific surface area is declined to some extent (Table 1). The outstanding catalytic performance of Co-N-C/MCHS is attributed to the hollow hierarchically mesoporous structure and the synergistic effect between oxygen vacancy and Co-Nx active sites. Conclusions In summary, MnOx-CeO2 hollow hierarchically mesoporous sphere (Co-N-C/MCHS) is synthesized via an efficient hard template method and a layer-by-layer strategy in which solid silica sphere is sacrificial template, MnOx-CeO2 is the shell, and cobalt porphyrin is the precursor of Co-N-C. Co-N-C/MCHS displays well-defined morphology with hollow mesoporous structure as evidenced by various characteristics. A “silica-protective-layer-assisted” approach is demonstrated in the inhibition of the sintering of metal oxide hollow mesoporous sphere under high temperature. And Co-N-C/MCHS holds enhanced catalytic activity and high stability for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene. The hollow hierarchically mesoporous structure with larger specific surface and the synergistic effect between oxygen vacancy and Co-Nx active sites play a significant role in the improved catalytic performance. The manner of this facile strategy will encourage more preparation of metal oxide hollow porous sphere with excellent performance. Competing interest The authors declare no competing financial interest. Acknowledgements This work was supported from the State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing in China (No. SKCHOP201504) and the Key Laboratory of Mineralogy and Metallogeny in Chinese Academy of Sciences (No. KLMM20150103). coredata.dc:description: Metal oxide hollow sphere have emerged as a kind of promising nanostructured materials for catalysis, energy conversion, and storage capacity. Herein, a “silica-protective-layer-assisted” approach is adopted to synthesize Co-N-C supported MnOx-CeO2 hollow mesoporous spheres, which can effectively suppress the sintering of metal oxide. The metal oxide hollow mesoporous spheres are prepared through silica template, MnOx-CeO2 shell, cobalt porphyrin precursor, and silica protective layer via a layer-by-layer strategy. The Co-N-C/MnOx-CeO2 catalysts show a remarkable catalytic performance for the oxidation of ethylbenzene (ethylbenzene conversion to 44.5%). Moreover, the catalysts have well-defined morphology, homogeneously dispersed, high specific surface area and porous structure. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to the hollow hierarchically mesoporous structure and the synergistic effect between oxygen vacancy and Co-Nx active sites derived from the pyrolysis of cobalt-N4 macrocycles of cobalt porphyrin.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of Co-N-C grafted on well-dispersed MnOx-CeO2 hollow mesoporous sphere with efficient catalytic performance
